references: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
Hammerson, G. 1999.  Amphibians and reptiles in Colorado. Second edition. University Press of Colorado and Colorado Division of Wildlife.Niwot, Colorado, USA.
NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
Stebbins, R.C. 2003. A field guide to western reptiles and amphibians.  Third Edition. Houghton Mifflin, Boston.
Dixon, J. R. and J. E. Werler. 2000. Texas Snakes. University of Texas Press. Austin, Texas.
Degenhardt, W., Painter, C., and A. Price.  1996. Amphibians and reptiles of New Mexico. University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 429 pages.
habitat_description: Widely found in a variety of habitats, from temperate woodland and grassland to the tropics. Prefers vegetation that borders streams, lakes, ponds, sloughs, and marshes. This species retreats to water as it swims and speeds away from danger while remaining among the plant growth near the shore. The Western ribbon snake is found in South Wisconsin to Gulf Coast and through North eastern Mexico to Costa Rica; from sea level up to 2440 m in the Sierra Madre Oriental, Mexico (Stebbins 2003). In arid regions of Colorado, this species is likely to be found nearby permanent water. In Oklahoma, it is found in brush proximate to ponds and pools to dive if threatened or disturbed (Hammerson 1999). This species lives along brushy or grassy margins of still water bodies. Found in water-filled vehicle tracks, swamps, marshes, rice fields, ponds, lakes, springs, streams, and rivers. Even A known invader of soggy woodlands, still not considered a forest dweller (Dixon and Werler 2000).In New Mexico, this species is found along the Canadian River at Mills Canyon and the Lower Pecos drainage near Artesia, Carlsbad, and Roswell. Its habitat is comprised of rivers, streams, irrigation canals, ditches, stock tanks, rocky and intermittent creeks in which deep pools remain in the arid southwest (Degenhardt et al. 1996)
